docs.lead_paragraph: The bark Howling Wind sailed from Philadelphia on the 18th January, bound to Londonderry, with a full cargo of grain, and proceeded down the river in tow of the steamboat Uncle Sam. docs.abstract: Christine Penberthy letter on April 11 article about 1906 San Francisco earthquake questions preparedness for large-scale disaster in United States today
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''The Ground Shook, a City Fell, and the Lessons Still Rebound'' (April 11): A line in your article about the 1906 San Francisco earthquake is full of painful irony. If it happened today, ''the toll, the researchers conclude, would include several thousand dead, several hundred thousand homeless and more than $100 billion in damage.''

docs.snippet: Government agencies and the insurance industry are still tallying the cost of devastation from the earthquake here a week ago Monday, but Federal and state officials agree that it may be the most expensive natural disaster in American history.   J...
docs.lead_paragraph: Government agencies and the insurance industry are still tallying the cost of devastation from the earthquake here a week ago Monday, but Federal and state officials agree that it may be the most expensive natural disaster in American history. James Lee Witt, the head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said today that the cost of replacing the buildings that had been destroyed here and repairing the damage to structures, highways and water and power systems might exceed the record of $30 billion, caused when Hurricane Andrew struck South Florida and southern Louisiana in 1992.

headline.main: Quake Could Be Costliest U.S. Disaster

docs.abstract: Climatologists Dr Helmut E Landsberg (Md Univ) and Dr J Murray Mitchell Jr (NOAA), at annual AAAS meeting, decry recent predictions of an impending ice age or other climatic disasters, and question global effects of man-made air pollution on climate (M)

byline.original: By WALTER SULLIVAN Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: BOSTON, Feb. 21--Two authorities on climate change have termed irresponsible recent predictions of an impending ice age or other climatic disaster. The also said that any global effects of man-made air pollution on the climate to date remained obscure.

headline.main: 2 Climate Experts Decry Predictions of Disasters; Drought in Africa
